bibl.title: Letter from Blanton P. Seward to Laura Armistead Carter, November 27, 1931

div1.p: Seward inquires about maritime quarantine regulations. He also requests information regarding Henry Carter's opinion of Strobel's, Nott's and Nelson's yellow fever work.

div1.head: Letter from Blanton P. Seward to Laura Armistead Carter, November 27, 1931
div1.opener:
LEWIS-GALE HOSPITAL
ROANOKE, VIRGINIA
November 27, 1931.
DEPARTMENT OF SURGERY
W. R. WHITMAN, M. D.
PAUL DAVIS, M. D.
M. A. JOHNSON, JR., M. D.
UROLOGY
S. BEVERLY CARY, M. D.
DEPARTMENT OF INTERNAL MEDICINE
C. D. NOFSINGER, M. D.
D. P. SEWARD, M. D.
ROENTOEXOLOGY
J. T. McKINNEY, M. D.
Miss Laura A. Carter,
2030 Highland Ave.,
Birmingham, Ala.
My dear Miss Carter:-
div1.p:
Thank you so much for loaning me the reprint of the editorial
concerning your father. No doubt you have been thinking that I would not
return it since I have kept it so long. I have been looking over other
references and was delayed in getting to it. I appreciate very much the
use of it and I hope my tardiness in returning it to you has not
interrupted any of your work.

Dr. Carter was one of the world's great men; the work he did
in preventing yellow fever and malaria was of inestimable value. Some day
I presume a biography of him will be written and I am quite sure it will
be an interesting one. Perhaps you are working on it. As soon as I get a
chance I shall read the book which was begun by your father. I am sure it
is a valuable one, both from a historical and epidemiological standpoint.
I shall mention his work in my paper.

Near the end of the first column on the second page of the
editorial it is stated that “Regulations having been issued,----there was
thus begun under his charge the present system of maritime quarantine by the
service.” Did that apply to quarantine of ships carrying yellow fever until
the disease was eradicated, or to maritime quarantine in general? If it
applied to the latter, do you know whether the same system is employed now,
sixteen years after the editorial was written?

What opinion did your father have of the work of Strobel, of
South Carolina, Josiah C. Nott and Agrippa Nelson Bell? Strobel wrote an
interesting article on yellow fever about 1840, but he thought that the
disease was conveyed by fomites. Nott believed that insects, “animalcules”,
had something to do with the spread of the disease, but he did not say
anything, as far as I have learned, about the mosquito being the inter-
mediary host. As Dr. Robert Wilson stated in his article, “Dr. J. C. Nott
and the Transmission of Yellow Fever”, in the September issue of the Annals
of Medical History, one wonders how Nott failed to associate the disease with
the mosquito. Bell believed that yellow fever was transmitted by fomites.
However, he was one of the first, if not the first, to believe in strict
quarantine for the prevention of the spread of the disease. As you know, he
discovered the value of steam as a disinfecting agent in 1848, and put it to
use on the vessels, the “Vixen” and the “Mahones”. After that time he
believed that disinfection by steam should be employed along with quarantine.
He also believed that sulphur in the proportion of 3-4 pounds to 1000 square
feet was efficient for fumigating purposes. As far as I have learned Bell
was the first to disinfect ships, so he might be called the originator of
maritime sanitation. Is that correct? I have made notes on the work of each
of those three men to be included in my article.

If you have reprints of Dr. Carter's articles, “The Interval

ROANOKE, VIRGINIA
DEPARTMENT OF SURGERY
W. R. WHITMAN, M. D.
PAUL DAVIS, M. D.
M. A. JOHNSON, JR., M. D.
UROLOGY
S. BEVERLY CARY, M. D.
DEPARTMENT OF INTERNAL MEDICINE
C. D. NOFSINGER, M. D.
D. P. SEWARD, M. D.
ROENTOEXOLOGY
J. T. McKINNEY, M. D.
Miss Carter - 2
between Infecting and Secondary Cases of Yellow Fever”; “The Extrinsic
Incubation of Yellow Fever”, and “The Effect of Impounded Water on the
Incidence of Malaria”, I shall appreciate it if you will loan them to me.
I should like very much to read them. Which one of the two articles on
yellow fever led Reed and his co-workers to believe that the disease was
conveyed by a host, or did both play an equal part?

The editorial stated that in 1904 Dr. Carter's name was
presented conjointly with that of Finlay, for the Nobel prize. I presume
that prize was awarded.

After the cause of yellow fever was discovered, measures were
instituted for its eradication. No doubt Dr. Carter played a large part in
the institution of those measures, both in Cuba and in Panama. Do you
recall how long he was in Cuba and what the nature of his work was during
the five years he spent in Panama?

You were kind enough to ask for a reprint of my paper. I will
be glad to send you one, although it will be several months before it will
be completed. I am writing on the “Contributions of Southern Men to
Medicine and the Natural Sciences”, and my progress on it is slow because
the references are scattered and it takes a great deal of time even after
locating the references to go over them and to evaluate them. The article
has already attained greath length and there is much more to be added.

About a year before I came to Roanoke I met your cousin, Mr.
Carter Redd, of Richmond. I saw him a number of times and became very fond
of him. I remember hearing him say that he was a nephew of Dr. Carter and
was named for him.

Sometime when you come to Virginia you no doubt will be passing
through Roanoke, and when you do so I hope you will let me know as I
should like very much to have the pleasure of meeting you.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, Blanton P. Seward BPS/h
